Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: New Wearable for Body Focused Repetitive Behavior Detection
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project will result from providing an accurate real-time awareness solution for those who suffer from body-focused repetitive behaviors. Over 4% of Americans suffer from skin picking, hair pulling, and nail biting, the majority of whom resort to covering up the problem with makeup, gloves, wigs, and even tattoos due to treatment cost barriers and lack of effective tools to facilitate behavior change. While behavior therapy, and in particular habit reversal training, has shown efficacy, this method is traditionally burdened by unreliable journaling, a lack of access to treatment, and difficulty for patients to perform in real-time because of a lack of awareness. While real-time awareness devices do exist, there is room for improvement in detection accuracy. This project will examine feasibility of a novel sensor system within a wearable device that can significantly improve detection accuracy of BFRB-related behaviors.

This Small Business Innovation Research Phase I project will develop and validate a novel wearable sensing system used to detect subtle movements associated with BFRBs that is suitable for large-scale manufacturing. We believe the proposed wearable system can improve the efficacy of leading behavior therapy methods. To accomplish these goals, early studies will focus on three main objectives. First, the team will investigate the best electrical and spatial configuration of the proposed sensors in a tightly controlled test setup. Second, the team will integrate the optimal configuration into a device suitable for testing and validate the integrity of the sensor output on individuals. Finally, the team will develop a proof-of-concept BFRB recognition algorithm under ideal, low-noise conditions.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
A novel sensor was designed, manufactured, and tested in a wrist-worn wearable system. Preliminary results showed that combining the novel sensor outputs with off-the-shelf motion sensor outputs improve the detection accuracy of certain body-focused-repetitive behaviors, especially hair-pulling (trichotillomania), skin-picking (dermatillomania), and scratching (eczema). The success of this work strongly supports continued research and development to bring this new technology to market.

The project goals were achieved in three key objectives.

In Key Objective 1 (KO1), prototype sensors were constructed using off-the-shelf materials, then integrated into a form-factor suitable for benchtop testing. The benchtop test system was designed to fully explore the capabilities of the new sensor and included all necessary amplifiers, filters, and digital interfaces to other measurements systems. Test software was written to guide participant experiments and store the outputs. Results were analyzed which drove the component choice for wearable integration.

In Key Objective 2 (KO2), supporting electronics were integrated into a wrist-worn wearable enclosure for supervised data capture. This was a significant effort that involved miniaturizing the circuits to fit in an off-the-shelf wearable enclosure and designing controlled experiments with participants. The results of this objective included the battery-powered wearable device and new data that characterized the novel sensor’s interaction with the wrist under motion conditions.

In Key Objective 3 (KO3), the data resulting from the supervised experiments were used to develop a preliminary behavior detection algorithm. The participants were asked to simulate behaviors of interest (e.g. skin-picking) and also to perform benign behaviors (e.g. typing). Naïve algorithms were implemented to classify sensor samples as “behavior” (skin-picking) or “not behavior” (benign) and its performance was evaluated. While this is a continued effort, preliminary results showed a naïve algorithm using the novel sensor and motion sensor together significantly improved the detection performance compared to the motion sensor alone. These exciting results confirm the utility of the novel sensor and support additional research and development efforts.

Finally, HabitAware has partnered with leading sensor manufacturers, tool suppliers, and electronics manufacturing facilities to develop versions of the novel sensor suitable for mass-production. Future work includes testing these newly tooled sensors in a custom-molded wearable enclosure, developing a remote data capture system for in-field testing, and developing scalable detection algorithms under a variety of realistic scenarios among other important objectives.
